new_marks.note: True. Hsu et al (2022) provide the first observational study of HIV remission in a woman. The abstract for the study (number 65, IMPAACT P1107) can be found here: https://www.iasusa.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/30-1s-3.pdf

range.commonAncestorContainer: “Umbilical stem cells are attractive,” Dr. Deeks said. “There’s something magical about these cells and something magical perhaps about the cord blood in general that provides an extra benefit.”
range.endText: “Umbilical stem cells are attractive,” Dr. Deeks said. “There’s something magical about these cells and something magical perhaps about the cord blood in general that provides an extra benefit.”

new_marks.note: True. According to the abstract provided by Hsu et al (2022), “We report on a woman in ART-free HIV-1 remission for 14 months following CCR5∆32 homozygous cord blood (CB) and CD34-selected haploidentical stem cell transplant (haplo-cord SCT) for acute myeloid leukemia (AML).” Find the rest of the abstract here: https://www.iasusa.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/30-1s-3.pdf.

new_marks.note: True. This patient was treated as part of IMPAACT P1107, "an observational study of persons living with HIV in the U.S. who undergo transplantation with CCR5Δ32 cord blood stem cells for treatment of cancer or other illness," according to its website (https://www.impaactnetwork.org/news/2022/impaact-p1107-team-presents-first-known-case-woman-hiv-remission). Information about the status of IMPAACT P1107 as a clinical trial are available here: https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT02140944.

new_marks.text: third person to date to be cured of HIV
new_marks.note: True. In addition to the current patient, there were two previous patients who were reported cured of HIV. The studies of the three patients are summarized in the Hutter et al (2009) (https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa0802905), Gupta et al (2019) (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-019-1027-4), and Hsu et al (2022) (https://www.iasusa.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/30-1s-3.pdf, #65), respectively.

range.commonAncestorContainer: “Umbilical stem cells are attractive,” Dr. Deeks said. “There’s something magical about these cells and something magical perhaps about the cord blood in general that provides an extra benefit.”

new_marks.text: donor who was naturally resistant to the virus that causes AIDS
new_marks.note: True. Hsu et al (2022) report that this patient has been treated with umbilical cord blood containing a mutation that is known to be resistant to HIV infection. See Schmidt et al (1996) for foundational results about this resistance: https://www.nature.com/articles/382722a0.

new_marks.note: True. The team that reported the latest HIV cure is composed of researchers. Their names are JingMei Hsu, Koen Van Besien, Marshall J. Glesby, Anne Coletti, Savita G. Pahwa, Meredith Warshaw, Amanda Golner, Frederic Bone, Nicole Tobin, Marcie Riches, John W. Mellors, Renee Browning, Deborah Persaud, and Yvonne Bryson. Their institutional affiliations can be found here: https://www.iasusa.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/30-1s-3.pdf.

new_marks.note: True. The abstract for the talk where this patient's results were announced is here (number 65): https://www.iasusa.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/30-1s-3.pdf.

new_marks.note: Somewhat false. Although the 2022 Conference on Retroviruses and Opportunistic Infections was scheduled to take place in person in Denver, it was converted to a fully virtual conference. The conference organizers issued refunds to participants who registered for in-person attendance: https://www.croiconference.org/croi-2022-refunds-for-converting-an-in-person-to-virtual-registration-will-begin-processing-next-week.

new_marks.note: True. Of the patients considered cured of HIV/AIDS, this patient is the first whose cure involved umbilical cord blood. See Hsu et al (2018) for more details: https://ashpublications.org/blood/article/132/Supplement%201/2184/261755.

new_marks.text: receiving the cord blood to treat her acute myeloid leukemia
new_marks.note: True. Hsu et al (2018) and Hsu et al (2022) describe this patient's treatment for acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in the following, respective studies: https://ashpublications.org/blood/article/132/Supplement%201/2184/261755 and https://www.iasusa.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/30-1s-3.pdf.

new_marks.text: cancer that starts in blood-forming cells in the bone marrow
new_marks.note: True. Lowenberg et al (1999) describe acute myeloid leukemia here: https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/nejm199909303411407.

new_marks.text: in remission and free of the virus for 14 months
new_marks.note: Somewhat true. According to the timeline outlined by Hsu et al (2018) and Hsu et al (2022, #65), this patient's remission (14 months after stopping ART) began in November or December 2021. The patient would have stopped ART in or around September 2020. The respective studies are available using the following links: https://ashpublications.org/blood/article/132/Supplement%201/2184/261755, https://www.iasusa.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/30-1s-3.pdf.

new_marks.text: without the need for potent HIV treatments known as antiretroviral therapy
new_marks.note: Somewhat true. According to the timeline outlined by Hsu et al (2018) and Hsu et al (2022, #65), this patient's remission (14 months after stopping ART) began in November or December 2021. The patient would have stopped ART in or around September 2020. The respective studies are available using the following links: https://ashpublications.org/blood/article/132/Supplement%201/2184/261755, https://www.iasusa.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/30-1s-3.pdf.

new_marks.text: The two prior cases occurred in males
new_marks.note: True. Hutter et al (2009) shows that the first patient, known as the "Berlin Patient" was a man (https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa0802905) and Gupta et al (2019) states that the second patient, known as the "London Patient", was a man (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-019-1027-4).
